childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1967-1979

You were born the year the Summer of Love bloomed in San Francisco, though you experienced none of the free love and all of the subsequent hangovers. Your parents watched hippies on television and probably tutted. The Six-Day War reshaped the Middle East in less than a week. Thurgood Marshall became the first Black Supreme Court Justice. The first Super Bowl happened, and Green Bay won, which is the kind of trivia that makes you useful at bar games.

Your earliest memories are Vietnam-era America. The draft loomed over your older relatives. Anti-war protests played out on the evening news between dinner and bedtime. Nixon was president by the time you were two, and Watergate was background noise to your kindergarten years. You didn't understand what was happening, but you knew adults were angry and the president was a bad man.

You grew up in an America that still had rotary phones bolted to kitchen walls, three television channels, and no seatbelt laws. Your playground equipment was made of metal that got hot enough to brand skin. You drank from garden hoses. You rode bikes without helmets. Somehow, enough of you survived to become a generation.

The economy of your childhood was stagflation—inflation and stagnation happening simultaneously, which economists said was impossible until it wasn't. Your parents waited in gas lines during the 1973 oil crisis. You watched adults panic about things they couldn't control, which turned out to be excellent preparation for adulthood.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Gen X, born between 1965 and 1980. That's roughly 65 million Americans, sandwiched between the massive Baby Boom and the equally massive Millennial generation. You're the middle child of demographics—overlooked, underestimated, and quietly running everything while everyone argues about Boomers and Millennials.

The defining trait of Gen X is self-reliance, forged by necessity. You were latchkey kids before that term existed. Your parents worked. Divorce rates doubled during your childhood. You came home to empty houses and raised yourselves on after-school television and microwave dinners. This made you independent, skeptical of institutions, and very good at entertaining yourself.

Your generation doesn't get the attention that Boomers and Millennials do, which is frankly how you prefer it. You watched Boomers get credit for changing the world and blame for ruining it. You watched Millennials get mocked for existing. You slipped through the middle, collected your paychecks, and avoided the discourse.

Gen X is pragmatic where Boomers were idealistic and Millennials were optimistic. You saw the '60s idealism curdle into '70s cynicism. You grew up during Watergate and the Cold War. You don't believe in saviors or systems. You believe in getting things done and going home.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Graduate premiered, and Dustin Hoffman's confused face would become the defining expression of your entire generation. Bonnie and Clyde reinvented movie violence. In the Heat of the Night won Best Picture, and Sidney Poitier's 'They call me Mr. Tibbs' line entered the language permanently.

Musically, 1967 was the year the Beatles released Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, which your parents probably owned on vinyl. The Doors, Jefferson Airplane, and Jimi Hendrix were redefining what rock could be. Aretha Franklin demanded R-E-S-P-E-C-T. The Monterey Pop Festival happened that June, three months before Woodstock made festivals a thing.

Your childhood was Saturday morning cartoons—Scooby-Doo, The Flintstones, Speed Racer. You watched Sesame Street from its 1969 launch. Your teenage years were MTV, which premiered when you were fourteen and taught you that music could be visual. You could probably still recite the lyrics to 'Video Killed the Radio Star.'

High school was John Hughes movies. You watched The Breakfast Club and felt seen in ways previous generations of teenagers never were. Sixteen Candles, Pretty in Pink, Ferris Bueller's Day Off—these weren't just movies, they were your generational autobiography. Even if your high school was nothing like the ones on screen, the feelings were exactly right.

By your twenties, grunge arrived and soundtracked your cynicism. Nirvana's 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' was the anthem of people who refused to have anthems. Kurt Cobain's death hit harder than any celebrity death had a right to, probably because he articulated something your generation felt but couldn't say.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the first handheld calculator was invented—a device the size of a small suitcase that cost thousands of dollars and could only do basic math. The first ATM opened in London. The technology of 1967 was analog, mechanical, and absolutely certain that the future would have flying cars.

Your childhood tech was rotary phones, television with rabbit ears, and transistor radios. You learned to type on actual typewriters in high school—manual ones, where you had to punch the keys like you meant it. The correction fluid was called Wite-Out, and using too much meant starting the page over.

You were seventeen when the IBM PC launched. Twenty-two when the Macintosh arrived. You're old enough to remember computing before the mouse, before the graphical interface, before any of this was easy. You learned DOS commands. You survived WordPerfect.

The internet entered your life in your late twenties or early thirties, which means you remember what email was like before spam, what the web was like before ads, and what social life was like before social media. You adapted to the digital age, but you didn't grow up in it. This gives you perspective younger people lack and occasionally makes you insufferable about it.

You've witnessed the entire arc of modern technology—from party lines to smartphones, from card catalogs to Google, from handwritten letters to texts. You remember when long-distance calls cost money. You remember when getting directions meant stopping at a gas station. You remember when being unreachable was the default, not a choice.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were one when Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy were assassinated within months of each other, in 1968. You don't remember it, but it shaped everything that came after. The hope of the early '60s died that year, and America entered a decade of cynicism you absorbed through osmosis.

You were seven during Watergate. You watched Nixon resign on television when you were seven. The lesson was clear: authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust nothing. This became the generational operating system.

You were twelve when the Vietnam War ended. You'd grown up with it as background noise—body counts on the evening news, older kids worrying about the draft, protesters and counter-protesters arguing about patriotism. When it ended, there was no victory, just exhaustion.

You were thirteen when the Bicentennial happened—America's 200th birthday, celebrated with tall ships and fireworks and aggressive optimism that felt forced. A year later, Star Wars arrived and taught your generation to believe in simple stories about good versus evil, which real life kept refusing to provide.

You were twenty-two when the Berlin Wall fell. Twenty-four when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War you'd grown up terrified of—the nuclear drills, the bomb shelters, the casual assumption that civilization could end any Tuesday—was suddenly over. History, Francis Fukuyama declared, had ended. History disagreed.

You were thirty-four on September 11, 2001. You were established adults by then—careers, mortgages, maybe kids. You watched the towers fall and understood immediately that everything was about to change. The world your children would grow up in would be nothing like the one you remembered.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the mid-to-late 1980s, during the Reagan boom. Jobs existed. The economy was growing. You could actually get hired straight out of college if you had a degree, and even without one, there were options. This was before 'entry-level requires five years experience' became standard.

Your generation invented the term 'workaholic' and then became them. You were the first generation to normalize 60-hour weeks as a badge of honor. You stayed late because staying late was what ambitious people did. Work-life balance was a phrase that wouldn't be invented for another decade, and when it arrived, you were suspicious of it.

You survived multiple economic cycles—the 1987 stock market crash, the early '90s recession, the dot-com bust, the 2008 financial crisis. Each one taught you that stability is temporary and companies will sacrifice you without hesitation. You learned to be loyal to your skills, not your employer, because employers sure as hell weren't loyal to you.

You're the generation that got caught in the middle management squeeze. Too old to be digital natives, too young to have accumulated pension wealth before pensions disappeared. You trained Millennials who got promoted over you. You watched Boomers refuse to retire, blocking your advancement. You adapted and kept working because what else was there to do?

By your late fifties, you've probably wondered if retirement is even possible. The goal posts keep moving. Social Security's future is uncertain. Your 401(k) took multiple hits. The pensions your parents counted on don't exist. You'll probably work longer than you planned, and you've made peace with that, or at least stopped complaining about it.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You dated before the internet, which means you met people in person—at school, at work, at bars, through friends. There was no algorithm. There was no swiping. You had to talk to actual humans in real time with no preview of their interests, politics, or relationship history. It was terrifying and inefficient and somehow it worked.

Your generation had the highest divorce rates of any generation, partly because your parents' divorces normalized ending unhappy marriages and partly because you were the first generation where women had enough economic independence to leave. You've probably been divorced yourself, or know plenty of people who are. The stigma your parents' generation felt about divorce doesn't apply to you.

You learned to communicate through letters, then phone calls, then email, then text. You've adapted to every new communication technology while maintaining the ability to actually call someone when it matters. You find it genuinely strange that younger people are afraid of phone calls.

Your relationships were shaped by the latchkey experience. You learned early that you couldn't rely on people to be there, so you built independence into your personality. This makes you good at being alone and sometimes bad at asking for help. Therapy, which your generation finally destigmatized, has probably helped with this.

If you have kids, they're probably Millennials or early Gen Z. You raised them differently than you were raised—more present, more intentional, more aware of their feelings. Whether this was better or just different is still being determined.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were twelve during the 1979 energy crisis and the inflation spike that followed. Twenty during the 1987 stock market crash. Thirty-three during the dot-com bust. Forty-one during the 2008 financial crisis. You've watched the economy explode approximately once per decade, which has made you either a careful planner or completely fatalistic, depending on your temperament.

Your generation was the first to fully experience the shift from pensions to 401(k)s. Your parents retired with defined benefits. You retired—or will retire—with whatever the stock market decides to give you. This transferred all the risk from employers to employees, which was sold as 'freedom' but felt more like 'abandonment.'

You bought houses when they were still affordable—at least compared to now. The median home price in 1990 was about $120,000. You might have complained about it at the time, but compared to what Millennials face, you got a deal. This is probably a sore subject at family gatherings.

You've been saving for retirement since your twenties because no one was going to save for you. You maxed out your 401(k) contributions. You invested in index funds before index funds were cool. You did everything the financial advisors told you to do, and you're still worried it won't be enough.

Your financial psychology is defined by self-reliance because every institution that was supposed to provide security—employers, government, the economy itself—failed to deliver. You trust yourself with money because you've learned, repeatedly, that trusting anyone else is a gamble.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is your reflexive cynicism. You were so burned by the broken promises of the '70s and '80s that you stopped believing promises could be kept. This protected you from disappointment but also made you slow to act on things that might actually work. Sometimes systems can be improved. Sometimes collective action matters. Your cynicism can become an excuse for inaction.

You raised your children to be more emotionally available than your own parents were, but you didn't always model emotional availability yourselves. You knew intellectually that talking about feelings was important, but doing it felt unnatural. Your kids might be better at emotional expression, but they learned it despite you, not from you.

Your self-reliance can tip into stubborn refusal to ask for help. You figured things out alone because you had to. This became a point of pride. But not everything needs to be figured out alone, and sometimes asking for help is faster and smarter. You know this. You have trouble doing it.

You've largely stepped back from generational discourse, letting Boomers and Millennials fight while you watch from the sidelines. This feels like maturity but might actually be abdication. You have perspective that could be useful. You have institutional power that could be leveraged. Instead, you're quietly running companies while avoiding the conversation entirely.

Your generation was slow to recognize systemic problems because you were so focused on individual solutions. Climate change, inequality, institutional racism—these require collective action, which your generation instinctively mistrusts. You survived by adapting individually. But some problems can't be solved by individual adaptation alone.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1987-1997): You entered adulthood during the Reagan/Bush years, when the economy was strong and jobs were findable. You were young during the dot-com boom's early days, old enough to ride it but not foolish enough to bet everything on it. This was your hustling decade—building careers, figuring out adult relationships, probably getting married for the first time. The Cold War ended. The future seemed open.

Your 30s (1997-2007): The decade of settling in. Careers stabilized. Kids arrived, if they were going to arrive. The dot-com bust dented your confidence but not your portfolio, if you were smart. September 11 happened. Everything felt heavier after that. You were raising children in an America that felt more dangerous than the one you'd grown up in, even though statistically it wasn't.

Your 40s (2007-2017): The 2008 financial crisis hit right as you entered your peak earning years. Some of you lost jobs. Many lost home equity. All lost faith in the idea that hard work guaranteed stability. You rebuilt, because that's what your generation does, but the rebuilding was harder this time. Your kids became teenagers, then adults. Your parents got older. You became the sandwich generation—responsible for everyone, supported by no one.

Your 50s (2017-2027): You're here now, or close to it. The pandemic hit. Remote work became possible just as you were becoming senior enough to hate it. You've probably started thinking seriously about retirement—what it means, whether it's possible, what you'd even do with the time. You're tired in ways you weren't tired at 40. But you're also clearer about what matters.

Your 60s and beyond (2027+): Retirement, if you can afford it, will probably come in your mid-to-late 60s. You'll have fewer guaranteed benefits than your parents' generation but more savings than your children's. You'll be the generation that remembers both the analog and digital worlds, which will make you either fascinating or annoying to younger people. You'll have grandchildren who can't imagine life without smartphones. You'll try to explain what it was like, and they won't believe you.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.5 million people born in 1967. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million Americans, making it the smallest generation between the massive Baby Boom and the equally massive Millennial cohort. You're demographically outnumbered coming and going.

Compared to Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're more skeptical and less idealistic. Boomers believed they could change the world. You watched them try and fail. Boomers got cheap college, affordable housing, and secure pensions. You got student loans, housing bubbles, and 401(k)s. Boomers protested institutions. You learned to work around them.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more self-reliant and less collaborative. Millennials were raised by helicopter parents who managed their lives. You were raised by absent parents who told you to figure it out. Millennials believe in systems and participation. You believe in survival and pragmatism. They're optimists who keep getting disappointed. You're pessimists who are occasionally pleasantly surprised.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you might as well be from different planets. They've never known a world without the internet. You remember installing it. They organize collective action on social media. You organize nothing and prefer it that way. They're anxious about everything. You're anxious about nothing because you've already decided nothing will work out anyway.

Your life expectancy is 78-79 years, assuming current trends hold. Your generation has better health outcomes than previous generations in some ways—you smoke less, exercise more—but worse in others, particularly around addiction and despair. You're the generation that normalized therapy and antidepressants, which is both sad and useful.

Your defining trait is survival. You adapted to every economic collapse, every technological shift, every institutional failure. You didn't thrive—that's a word for people who had more help than you did. But you survived. And you're still standing, which is more than the systems that were supposed to support you can say.

year_events: The Summer of Love happened in San Francisco
The Six-Day War reshaped the Middle East
Thurgood Marshall became the first Black Supreme Court Justice
The first Super Bowl was played
The first successful human heart transplant was performed
